resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Pulmonary sequestration. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.

Medscape Reference provides information on this topic. You may need to register to view the medical textbook, but registration is free.
Pediatric Pulmonary Sequestration
Pulmonary Sequestration Imaging
Orphanet is a European reference portal for information on rare diseases and orphan drugs. Access to this database is free of charge.

The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Pulmonary sequestration is a rare congenital (present from birth) malformation where non-functioning lung tissue is separated from the rest of the lung and supplied with blood from an unusual source, often an artery from systemic circulation.[2217][2218][12033][12034] Pulmonary sequestrations may be defined as intralobular or extralobular, depending on their location.[2218][12033][12034] Symptoms may include a chronic  or recurrent cough, respiratory distress or lung infection.[12033] Treatment depends on the location and may involve surgery.[2218][12033]

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the symptoms of extralobar pulmonary sequestration?
basicQuestions.answerText: Typical symptoms seen in infants with extralobular pulmonary sequestration include cough, respiratory problems, feeding difficulties, or congestive heart failure, although many infants have no symptoms.[7253][2218] Chronic infections are not common.[7253] Extralobular pulmonary sequestration is commonly associated with other birth defects, including diaphragmatic hernia and other lung malformations such as congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation and bronchogenic cysts, pectus excavatum, pericardial problems, and duplication cysts.[7253] This type of sequestration accounts for 25 percent of all sequestrations.[12034]

references.authors: Erin G. Brown, Clifford Marr, Diana Farmer
references.articleTitle: Extralobar pulmonary sequestration: The importance of intraoperative vigilance
references.bookWebsiteJournalTitle: Journal of Pediatric Surgery Case Reports

references.authors: Dong J, Cai Y, Chen, et al.
references.articleTitle: A Case Report and a Short Literature Review of Pulmonary Sequestration Showing Elevated Serum Levels of Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9.

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the symptoms of intralobular pulmonary sequestration?
basicQuestions.answerText: Intralobular pulmonary sequestration is characterized by recurrent infections, hemoptysis, or pleural effusion.[12033][12034] A chronic or recurrent cough is common.[12033] A chest radiograph may reveal a solid or fluid (cystic) lesion in the lower lobe, more often on the left side. Intralobular pulmonary sequestration is often diagnosed later than extralobular pulmonary sequestration, in childhood or adulthood.[2218][12033] It accounts for 75 percent of all sequestrations and affects males and females in equal numbers.[2218][12034] Intralobular pulmonary sequestration is not commonly associated with other congenital anomalies.[2218][12033]

references.authors: Dong J, Cai Y, Chen, et al.
references.articleTitle: A Case Report and a Short Literature Review of Pulmonary Sequestration Showing Elevated Serum Levels of Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9.

references.authors: Mazzarella G, Iadevaia C, Guerra G, Rocca A, Corcione N, Rossi G, Amore D, Brunese L, Bianco A
references.articleTitle: Intralobar pulmonary sequestration in an adult female patient mimicking asthma: a case report.

basicQuestions.answerText: While the vast majority of pulmonary sequestration cases occur in isolation (without any family history), rare familial cases have been reported.[2220][12040][12041] Therefore, a genetic component  cannot be ruled out.

references.bookWebsiteJournalTitle: Murray & Nadel's Textbook of Respiratory Medicine, 4th ed.

references.authors: Abuhamad AZ, Bass T, Katz ME, Heyl PS.
Becker J, Hernandez A, Dipietro M, Coran AG
references.articleTitle: Identical twins concordant for pulmonary sequestration communicating with the esophagus and discordant for the VACTERL association.

basicQuestions.questionText: How might intralobular pulmonary sequestration be treated?
basicQuestions.answerText: Due to the risk for infection and bleeding, intralobar pulmonary sequestrations are usually removed, either by segmentectomy (removal of part of the lung) or lobectomy (removal of the full lobe). Angiography along with CT scan (with or without contrast) and MRI are generally used to visualize the origins of the blood supply before surgery is performed.[12033]

basicQuestions.questionText: How might extralobular pulmonary sequestration be treated?
basicQuestions.answerText: Traditional treatment of extralobular pulmonary sequestration involves surgical removal via mini-thoracotomy for patients that are experiencing symptoms. Less invasive surgery techniques may include thorascopic surgery and coil embolization.[7253]

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
